results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 16]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

In Reel 16 the royal couple visit regional Victorian towns; including ‘behind the scenes’ shots of press and radio recording the tour, and the enthusiastic welcome given by the citizens of rural Victoria.

Detailed Description Reel 16:

Opens with Title “Shepparton”, followed by footage of crowds waiting to see the royal visitors. 00:00:26:00 Queen and Duke arrive and meet some locals. 00:00:36:00 Queen, Duke and local Mayor mount dais for speeches (by Mayor and Queen). 00:00:58:00 Queen and Duke re-enter car for drive through town; crowds line streets. Camera stays focussed on car, with little footage of Shepparton streets. 00:01:13:00 shot includes some local buildings and shops and a sign for the “P & O Cafe” is visible. 00:01:18:00 Title “Tatura”, followed by footage of crowds waiting to see the royal visitors, including school children in uniform. 00:01:39:00 Queen and Duke arrive in car, meet some locals. 00:02:16:00 Queen makes speech from dais. 00:02:19:00 “Tatura” sign at local railway station segues straight into footage of crowds along tracks taken from moving train, then views of orchards (or vines?) and paddocks also shot from moving train. 00:03:12:00 Title “Echuca”, followed by a shot of the Murray River with buildings and boats moored at banks. 00:03:23:00 street parade of children (beneath a series of floral arches), including Brownies and Girl Guides in uniform. 00:03:41:00 waiting crowds shot from moving train with some town some buildings visible. 00:03:49:00 Queen and Duke get into car. 00:03:58:00 Queen and Duke listening to speech (by Mayor). 00:04:13:00 good shot of assembled press photographers standing for national anthem. 00:04:22:00 Queen makes speech. 00:04:33:00 back into car for street tour. Footage of local streets and buildings, and crowds lining roadway. 00:05:11:00 car arrives at railway station. 00:05:19:00 close-up of Queen and Duke waving from back of train. 00:05:26:00 Title “Rochester”, followed by footage of waiting crowds. 00:05:44:00 Boy Scouts in uniform marching past a public building in background (possibly school or town hall). 00:05:49:00 footage of “Royal” train coming into station, Queen and Duke disembark. 00:06:07:00 Queen and Duke meet and chat with locals, and walk along crowd-lined street. The flies are particularly bad, and both Queen and Duke are seen waving flies away between waving at the crowd. 00:06:28:00 street sign “Welcome Shire of Rochester”. 00:06:57:00 back to the railway station and onto train. Crowds waving and cheering. 00:07:30:00 good shot of reporter talking into microphone. 00:07:40:00 Title ” Bendigo”, followed by footage of waiting crowds from moving train, Queen emerging from railway station. 00:07:55:00 with Mayor in robes and chain. More footage of crowds and motorcade through streets follows. 00:08:41:00 appears to arrive at sportsground with crowds including Girl Guides and Brownies. 00:09:05:00 Queen addresses crowd from dais. 00:09:10:00 shot of press photographers kneeling and crouched on grass. 00:09:29:00 back in the car, Duke appears to remove something from back of Queen’s dress. 00:09:50:00 at decorated railway station (“Parcels Office and Cloak Room” sign). 00:10:03:00 car arrives at station. 00:10:22:00 footage of people along tracks and houses from moving train, orchards and landscape.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 15 includes the royal couple’s visit to the Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital, followed by a visit to the Victorian regional town of Benalla.

Detailed Description Reel 15:

Opens with Title “Repatriation General Hospital Heidelberg”, followed by footage of crowd outside including flag-waving children. 00:00:25:00 motorcade arrives through ranks of uniformed nurses at attention, and the Queen and Duke exit car and enter hospital building. 00:00:43:00 interior hospital shots; patient in bed wearing medals, patients and staff being greeted and spoken with. 00:01:13:00 outside the building, patients in dressing gowns - some in wheelchairs - gathered on grass. Queen and Duke mingle and chat. 00:02:26:00 Queen and Duke leave in car. 00:02:23:00 close-up of “Royal Train” with coat of arms on front. 00:02:28:00 close-up of train’s name-plate “Harold W Clapp” (named for Sir Harold Winthrop Clapp, former commissioner of Victorian Railways). 00:02:30:00 close-up of Victorian Railways officials in uniform, and train crew. 00:03:04:00 Title “Visit of Northern Victoria Benalla Friday, 5th. March. 1954.” followed by landscape shot out window of moving train, and exterior shots of train travelling and people gathered along tracks. 00:04:25:00 train arrives at Benalla Railway Station. Crowd and close-up shots of people waiting to greet Queen. 00:04:46:00 banner in crowd visible “Wangaratta Technical School”. 00:05:06:00 Queen and Duke exit station - shots of decorated exterior of Benalla Railway Station.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 14 contains footage of the royal tour visiting Warragul and the Latrobe Valley, followed by a visit to the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research.

Detailed Description Reel 14:

Opens with Title “Warragul”, followed by footage of Queen and Duke exiting railway station (?) and at 00:00:20:00 entering car. 00:00:30:00 flag-waving crowd of children, Queen and Duke mounting dais and waving to crowd. 00:00:43:00 Queen making speech. 00:00:55:00 child presents flowers. 00:01:09:00 locals presented. 00:01:38:00 footage is of crowd along tracks from moving train. 00:01:45:00 footage is of train itself moving along tracks and a distance shot as train moves through very flat grasslands. 00:02:04:00 Title “Visit of His Royal Highness to the University of Melbourne”, followed by very brief footage of flag flying over (presumably) a Melbourne University building. 00:02:17:00 Title “Visit of His Royal Highness to the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research”, followed by shots of the Institute buildings at Royal Melbourne Hospital. 00:03:12:00 the Duke arrives in open car, and greets waiting crowd and children before entering building, where we see some Institute equipment and staff at work. More footage of crowd outside. 00:03:59:00 the Duke exits, moves to car and is driven away.

In Reel 13 the royal couple visit towns in the Victorian region of Gippsland.

Detailed Description Reel 13:

Opens with Title “Visit to Gippsland Deplane at East Sale Aerodrome. Wednesday, 3rd. March, 1954”, followed by plane landing. 00:00:29:00 Queen and Duke exit plane. 00:01:07:00 motorcade through streets. 00:01:42:00 Queen and Duke exit car, mount dais, accompanied by local mayor. Queen makes speech. Locals are presented. 00:03:03:00 Queen and Duke re-enter car and motorcade drives through Sale streets. 00:04:15:00 footage switches to landscape and crowds outside moving train window. 00:04:29:00 Title “Traralgon”, followed by footage of the “Royal Train” pulling into station. 00:04:50:00 royal couple climb steps to dais. 00:05:12:00 crowd of Girl Guides in uniform, presentation of flowers to Queen on dais, crowd of Brownies in uniform (next to Girl Guides). 00:05:35:00 motorcade through Traralgon streets with Town Hall and Bank buildings just seen in background. 00:05:47:00 motorcade passes a Mobil oil station, with red 1950s bowsers outside. 00:06:25:00 footage from moving train, including an open cut coal mine. 00:06:40:00 Title “Yallourn”. No footage after 00:06:45:00 (film torn).

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

A highlight of Reel 12 is the footage of a garden party held at Government House; this Reel also includes further footage of Flinders Naval Depot (now HMAS Cerberus).

Detailed Description Reel 12:

Begins with continuation of Flinders Naval Depot visit by Duke (seen in Reel 11), with various parades and marches of naval personnel past dais where the Duke stands. 00:01:22:00 formation flyover. 00:01:30:00 Duke driven to another area and reviews what appear to be naval officers in training. More footage of naval personnel, marching, saluting, and presenting arms. 00:04:08:00 Duke re-boards train which moves off. 00:04:40:00 Title “Combined Women’s Organisations Luncheon”, followed by close-ups of women attendees dressed in their best. 00:05:05:00 crowd of flag-waving children holding banner “Melbourne Orphanage greets The Queen”. It is clearly a hot day - members of the crowd are holding sun-shades and covering their heads. 00:05:40:00 the Queen arrives. 00:06:02:00 to 00:06:06:00 a couple of children in the crowd can be seen holding “box brownie” cameras, keenly waiting to photograph the Queen. 00:06:27:00 Title “Garden Party at Government House”, followed by shots of guests arriving for the garden party. Wonderful shots of fashions and hats. Footage of guests strolling in gardens, with Government House building behind. Queen and Duke exit the building at 00:07:17:00 and walk towards crowd on grass. Footage of the crowd of guests in the garden is shot from a vantage point high in the building. Queen greets and talks with some of the guests, then enters a garden marquee. The Reel finishes with shot of Royal Standard flying over Government House.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

In Reel 11, we see the Queen dedicating the forecourt and eternal flame additions to Melbourne’s Shrine of Remembrance. The Queen and other audience are seen arriving at Melbourne’s Princess Theatre. The Duke visits the Flinders Naval Depot (now HMAS Cerberus).

Detailed Description Reel 11:

Opens with Title “Shrine of Remembrance Dedication of Additions”, followed by aerial shots of Shrine of Remembrance with waiting crowds, and Queen’s car driving along St. Kilda Road. 00:00:35:00 car arrives at the Shrine, driving slowly through waving crowds. 00:00:41:00 Queen and Duke exit their car and are greeted (by an official party including Governor Brooks). 00:01:00:00 the party walk across the Shrine forecourt with Government House and Melbourne Observatory buildings visible in the background. Party climb steps and enter Shrine; at 00:01:34:00 an entertaining shot of a collective bow and curtsey at top of Shrine steps. The National Anthem is played and speeches made (NOTE: this footage does NOT include footage of Queen lighting Eternal Flame contained in Reel 1). There is a break in the film before a shot of the Eternal Flame smoking. Official party walk down steps and across the forecourt to the Eternal Flame. 00:03:18:00 Queen and Duke re-enter car and leave. 00:03:38:0 Title “Arrival at Princess Theatre Monday, 1st. March, 1954.”, followed by shots of Queen, Duke and other guests arriving at the Spring Street theatre in evening dress. 00:04:09:00 to 00:04:26:00 interior shots of the theatre (dress circle) and audience. 00:04:26:00 Title “Visit of His Royal Highness to Flinders Naval Depot Tuesday, 2nd. March, 1954.”, followed by train arriving (presumably at Flinders Naval Depot railway platform). 00:04:54:00 Duke exits train accompanied by William (Billy) McMahon (then Minister for Labour and National Service, later Prime Minister of Australia 1971-72) and is greeted by navy officers. Duke enters car and motorcade drives through streets lined with flag-waving children. 00:05:40:0 naval marching band and sailors on parade. Duke reviews troops, a short religious service is held, and the Duke makes a speech. 00:07:30:00 Band plays (probably Royal Australian Navy Band or Flinders Naval Depot Band). Sailors parade past saluting Duke.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 10 shows more of the special race-meeting held at Flemington Racecourse, the tennis at Kooyong, and a service held at St. Paul’s Cathedral.

Detailed Description Reel 10:

Opens with Title “Duke of Edinburgh Australian Cup” followed by race footage of the last stretch and race finish. 00:00:25:00 Title “Queen Elizabeth Stakes”, followed by footage of horses and jockeys in the mounting yard. 00:00:50:00 footage of entire race to 00:01:12:00 then horses - with jockeys still mounted - exit to mounting yards. 00:01:40:00 to 00:03:23:00 the Queen presents winners’ trophies. 00:03:44:00 Title “Tennis at Kooyong”, followed by shot of Kooyong Stadium (Kooyong Tennis Centre) scoreboard displaying “International Match Australia v Sth. Africa”, footage of game and crowd scenes. 00:04:05:00 - 00:05:34:00 Queen and Duke arrive separately and move to seats amongst crowd. 00:05:45:00 - 00:06:35:00 Queen presents trophies in middle of court. 00:06:36:00 Title “Divine Service Cathedral Church of St. Paul Sunday, 28th. February, 1954”, followed by shots of St Paul’s Cathedral and crowds outside. 00:07:01:0 a good shot of Flinders Street Station and the station verandas along Swanston St. 00:07:27:00 Queen and Duke arrive and enter Cathedral. 00:08:01:00 couple leave and re-enter car, driving off through waving crowds. Dignitaries and churchmen on steps of Cathedral, at 00:08:41:00 Robert Menzies (then Prime Minister of Australia) is seen leaving, acknowledging crowd and getting into car.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

In Reel 9 we see the Royal tour in the Victorian regional town of Hamilton, then attending a special race meeting at Flemington Racecourse.

Detailed Description Reel 9:

Starts with Title “Visit to Hamilton: Departure from Melbourne Airport (Overseas Terminal) Friday, February, 26th. 1954.” Tarmac and crowd scenes at Essendon (Melbourne) Airport. 00:01:06:00 Queen and Duke board plane. 00:01:36:00 plane taking off. 00:01:55:00 various officials boarding another plane. 00:02:53:00 plane landing. 00:03:02:00 arrival at Hamilton, Queen and Duke exit plane, followed by crowd scenes and presentation on dais. 00:03:43:00 motorcade through Hamilton (local streets and buildings) followed by greetings and crowd scenes at an official reception (at what appears to be a local sports ground). 00:04:56:00 Title “Flemington Race Meeting Saturday, February, 27th. 1954.” followed by shot of betting windows at Flemington, crowd scenes, people placing bets, close-ups of fashions and millinery styles. 00:05:35:00 Queen and Duke in open car, with mounted police. 00:05:59:00 greetings from VRC officials 00:07:15:00 mounting yard. 00:07:26:00 Title “Newmarket Handicap”, followed by interspersed scenes of crowd and horse-race. 00:08:01:00 Queen leaves stand and crowds begin to disperse.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:

Reel 8 captures the Queen opening the Victorian State Parliament, and the Queen and Duke meeting with Australian armed forces veterans at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG).

Detailed Description Reel 8:

Opens with Title “Opening of Parliament: Thursday, 25th. February, 1954.” followed by shots of Government House and gardens. 00:00:35:00 Queen (in state dress) and Duke exit and get into open car, which leaves Government House and moves along St. Kilda Road and city streets with crowd shots on the way. 00:02:06:00 inside State Parliament. 00:02:19:00 leaving State Parliament through crowds and back into car. 00:03:19:00 Title “Assembly of Ex-Servicemen’s and Women’s Organisations, Junior Legatees and War Widows. Melbourne Cricket Ground.” 00:03:30:00 marching military bands, veterans in wheelchairs, and arrival of Queen and Duke in open car, which drives around perimeter then to centre of ground. 00:05:06:00 Philip makes speech from dais. 00:05:20:00 children present flowers. 00:05:58:00 footage of various groups marching. 00:07:00:00 Queen and Duke leave dais and speak with veterans. 00:07:58 to end - Queen and Duke re-enter open car and leave Melbourne Cricket Ground.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Reel 7 shows us more of the crowds and celebrations in central Melbourne.

Detailed Description Reel 7:

Opens with crowd scenes and aerial shots of motorcade along Spring Street end of Bourke Street, then arrival of motorcade at Victorian State Parliament. 00:00:38:00 marching band playing along street in front of crowds in roadside bleachers. 00:00:53:00 out-of-focus street parade scenes. 00:01:09:00 Queens Guard marching band. 00:01:19:00 mounted police. 00:01:54:00 Queens Guard marches up Swanston Street from Princes Bridge (and a press photographer gets caught by camera and hurries out of shot). 00:02:17:00 - 00:02:44:00 footage of the massive crowd in Swanston Street. Various crowd scenes in Melbourne CBD and at Government House. Ends with shots of motorcade on Swanston Street with Melbourne Town Hall in the background, and police holding back the crowd on the street.
